Lecture notes and Past Exam Papers and solution could be found in http://www.math.ust.hk/~emarberg/teaching/2019/Math2121/

The first half of the course is basically DSE M2 stuff, it should not be too difficult to understand. Make sure that you understand the concepts of Linear Independence and subspace clearly, these two is the main concept to remember before the midterm.

The course content after the midterm is based on the stuff before the midterm, however, the calculations become more and more tedious, especially for orthonormal basics and Singular Value Decomposition, the result of these two are basically Matrices with entries of square roots and fractions.... so be careful of your calculations.

reviews.comment_content:
As a "first course on linear algebra", the content is quite well-designed. Starting from some basic matrix manipulation and computaion to some more advanced concepts and algorithms and applications. It's suitable for anyone who has no Linear Algebra background.

Not hard to follow, and not shallow in terms of depth of content.

The following content schedule throughout the semester is quoted from Eric's public class homepage https://www.math.hkust.edu.hk/~emarberg/teaching/2021/Math2121/. You may also change the "2021" in the URL to "2020"/"2019"/"2018"/"2017". Eric has a webpage for all these fall semesters that offers this course. You can see that the content each year is pretty much the same.

Week 1: Linear systems, row reduction to echelon form
Week 2: Vectors, matrix equations, linear independence
Week 3: Linear independence, linear transformations )
Week 4: Matrix multiplication, the inverse of a matrix
Week 5: Subspaces, bases, dimension
Week 6: Determinants
Week 7: Vector spaces, midterm
Week 8: Eigenvectors, and eigenvalues
Week 9: Similarity and diagonalisable matrices
Week 10: Complex eigenvalues, properties of eigenvalues
Week 11: Inner products, orthogonality, and projections
Week 12: Gram-Schmidt process, least-squares problems
Week 13: Symmetric matrices, SVDs
reviews.comment_teaching:
Eric has a double major from stanford and a PHD from MIT, so clearly he is a genuis. His understading about math is definately at a stage where he can just say something, and that sentence can be and should be memorized as a theory for us.

This semester, due to the pandemic, they adopted mix-mode teaching. L1 is purely online and L2 is F2F. But whichever section you are enrolled in, you can always watch the recording posted on the public course website from L1 zoom recording.

Personally, I would say, it's better to watch his lectures online instead of attending the class F2F. Because:
    1. Generally speaking, his pace of voice is rather slow. And it's just so easy to get sleepy when listening to his voice. 1.5xx speed of zoom recording is a pefect speed for listening to his lectures. And as he is a native speaker of English, 1.5xx doesn't make his voice unclear. It's just the right speed I think.
     2. Someone in a prvious review said his lectures are like some very decent Youtube videos without a Pause Button. I can't agree more on that. But when you watch Zoom recording, there is a pause button. You can pause and write down something he said that can be and should be memorized as a theory for us. (which happens quite often for me)

Generally, his teaches by following the lecture notes (i.e. making annotations whlie explaing, giving examples from time to time, and give some verbal "Eric's theory") He also uses Julia to do some demo during the lecture to help us visualize and understand some concepts or have a look at some applications of certain content covered in the lecture. They won't be covered in exams but they sometimes do promt better visualization and understading. The Youtube Link I put in the Workload Section may help as well.

Overall the teaching is good. Especially the "Eric's theory" part.

Eric also set up a discord server for the whole class, where you can ask questions (either about homeworks, logistics, grading cutoffs, etc.) And his reply is rather quick. So it's qiute easy to reach him out side of class.

Oh let me add one more thing: ERIC IS SO FREEKING DAMN HANDSOME

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Li is an excellent mathematician. In terms of linear algebra, he definitely possesses much knowledge. He is able to present every proof smooth and explain them well. However, sometimes he will become so excited and go beyond the syllabus. The major problem of him is that his voice is way too soft. It is not that easy to listen to his words.

He gave a review of the last lecture every time. This made us easier to follow. However, this also made the lecture became very tedious as you would feel like every time the content is the same. To some extent, this is the problem of the content as well. It seems like most things are very alike but just change of the terms.

Prof. Li use whiteboard all the time while not all of his writing can be found in lecture notes. As a result, I recommend you to jot down everything on the whiteboard. It can help you understand the proof as the steps from Prof. Li are clearer than lecture notes.

One weird thing is that in the lecture the professor will focus on proof and give you some very difficult examples. However, assignment and exams focus on computation instead and super easy. My recommendation is to try to understand the proof in lecture. If you really cannot follow, do not give up. You can still score high by just knowing the computation methods and basic concepts.

Recommended Text Book:
Linear Algebra and its Applications, by D. Lay, S. Lay, and J. McDonald, the 5th edition.

Content:
Chapter 1: Linear Equations in Linear Algebra
Chapter 2&3: Matrix and Determinants
Chapter 4: Vector Space
Midterm Examination
Chapter 5: Eigenvalues, Eigenvectors, and Orthogonality
Chapter 6: Orthogonal Projection and Least-Square Problem
Chapter 7: Symmetric Matrices and Quadratic Form
Final Examination
